TELEGRAPHIC ADDRESS 
"BUREDUC" WASHING -
TON, D. C. 
[WESTERN UNION CODE]

The Chinese Educational Mission

to the United States of America

2006 COLUMBIA ROAD

WASHINGTON, D. C.

November 24, 1913.

Mr. A. E. Stearns,

Principal, 
Phillips Academy,

Andover, Mass. 
My dear Mr. Stern:

I am glad to know that you have returned from 
your trip abroad.

be able can say have a

In regard to the registered letter addressed 
to I. C. Sun, I am sorry not to be able to give you any 
information concerning it. All that I can say is that 
all letters that I have received for F. Y. Sun have al -
ways been forwarded to him without delay, and there may 
have been one or two letters for his brother, but I do 
not remember of having received the letter referred to 
in your letter. However, I will see Fa Yuen and ask 
whether he has received any such letter forwarded to him, 
and will let you know.

By the way, Fa Yuen, has not been doing well 
in his studies and I have written to Mr. Tong's relative 
in Peking asking him to suggest to Sun's father, that it 
would be better to recall him as since he is not making 
any progress it would be waste of money to keep him here 
any longer. He was doing fairly well the first few 
months after he came down to Washington, but the principal 
of the school where he has been studying has written me 
that he did not care to have him return to school after 
the summer vacation.

Hoping you are enjoying good health, with kind 
regard, I am

Yours sincerely,

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter from Mr. Wong of the Chinese Educational Mission to the United States stating that he has no more information on the registered letter to Mr. L.C. Sun  but noting that all letters addressed to his brother, Fa Yuen Sun, have been forwarded. Mr. Wong reports that Fa Yuen Sun has not been doing well in his studies and suggests that Sun be recalled based on the school's recommendation.
